meaning:
\( \text{KE} = \frac{1}{2} mv^2 \)
Energy due to the motion of an object.

\( \text{PE} = mgh \)
Energy due to an object's position in a gravitational field.

\( v = v_0 + at \)
The velocity after a certain time under constant acceleration.

\( s = v_0t + \frac{1}{2} at^2 \)
The total distance covered under constant acceleration.

\( v^2 = v_0^2 + 2as \)
The velocity in relation to displacement and acceleration.

\( F = ma \)
The force required to accelerate an object.

\( F_{\text{gravity}} = mg \)
The force exerted on an object by gravity.

\( F_{\text{friction}} = \mu N \)
The resistive force experienced by a moving object.

\( p = mv \)
The amount of motion an object possesses.

term: Conservation of Momentum in a Collision
meaning:
\( m_1v_1 + m_2v_2 = (m_1 + m_2) v_f \)
Total momentum is conserved during a collision.

\( \text{KE} + \text{PE} = \text{constant} \)
Total energy remains constant in an isolated system.

\( W = Fd \cos(\theta) \)
The energy transfer through force over a distance.

\( P = \frac{W}{t} \)
The rate of work done or energy transferred.

\( \tau = r \times F \sin(\theta) \)
The rotational effect caused by a force.

\( \text{KE}_{\text{rotation}} = \frac{1}{2} I\omega^2 \)
The energy of a rotating object.

\( \alpha = \frac{\tau}{I} \)
The rate of change of angular velocity.

\( T = 2\pi \sqrt{\frac{L}{g}} \)
The time taken for a pendulum to complete one cycle.

\( v = \lambda f \)
The speed at which a wave propagates.

\( E = \frac{1}{2} kA^2 \)
The energy stored in a spring or oscillator.

\( V = IR \)
The relationship between voltage, current, and resistance.

\( P = IV \)
The power or energy per unit time in an electric circuit.

\( F = qE \)
The force exerted on an electric charge in an electric field.

\( \Phi = B \cdot A \cos(\theta) \)
The magnetic field passing through a surface.

\( F = Bqv \sin(\theta) \)
The force on a charge moving in a magnetic field.

\( \sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta = 1 \)
The fundamental trigonometric identity.

\( a^2 + b^2 = c^2 \)
The relationship between the sides of a right triangle.

\( \sin(a \pm b) = \sin a \cos b \pm \cos a \sin b \)
Trigonometric relations for the sum or difference of angles.

\( \sin(2\theta) = 2 \sin \theta \cos \theta \)
The formula for the sine of a double angle.

\( \cos(2\theta) = \cos^2 \theta - \sin^2 \theta \)
The formula for the cosine of a double angle.

\( \tan(2\theta) = \frac{2 \tan \theta}{1 - \tan^2 \theta} \)
The formula for the tangent of a double angle.

\( \sin^2 \theta = \frac{1 - \cos(2\theta)}{2} \)
The formula for the sine of a half angle.

\( \cos^2 \theta = \frac{1 + \cos(2\theta)}{2} \)
The formula for the cosine of a half angle.

\( \tan^2 \theta = \frac{1 - \cos(2\theta)}{1 + \cos(2\theta)} \)
The formula for the tangent of a half angle.

\( 1 + \tan^2 \theta = \sec^2 \theta \)
The relationship between tangent and secant.

\( \sin \theta = \frac{\text{opposite}}{\text{hypotenuse}} \)
\( \cos \theta = \frac{\text{adjacent}}{\text{hypotenuse}} \)
\( \tan \theta = \frac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta} \)
The basic definitions of sine, cosine, and tangent.

\( \tau = r \times F \)
The rotational equivalent of force, calculated as the perpendicular force applied at a distance from the pivot point.

\( W = \tau \theta \)
The work done by a torque over an angular displacement.

term: Angular Position, Displacement, Velocity and Acceleration
meaning: Angular position describes the orientation of an object in rotational motion. Displacement is the change in angular position. Angular velocity \( \omega \) is the rate of change of angular displacement, and angular acceleration \( \alpha \) is the rate of change of angular velocity.

\( \omega_f = \omega_i + \alpha t \)
This equation describes how angular velocity changes over time when a constant angular acceleration \( \alpha \) is applied. \( \omega_f \) is the final angular velocity, \( \omega_i \) is the initial angular velocity, and \( t \) is the time.

\( \theta = \omega_i t + \frac{1}{2} \alpha t^2 \)
This equation calculates the angular displacement \( \theta \) of an object under constant angular acceleration. \( \omega_i \) is the initial angular velocity, \( \alpha \) is the angular acceleration, and \( t \) is the time.

\( \sum \tau = 0 \)
A system is in rotational equilibrium if the sum of torques acting on it is zero, meaning there is no net angular acceleration.
Static equilibrium means no motion (\( \omega = 0 \)), while dynamic equilibrium means constant rotation (\( \alpha = 0 \)).

\( I = \sum m_i r_i^2 \)
The total moment of inertia of a system is the sum of all individual masses multiplied by the square of their distances from the axis.

\( I = I_{\text{cm}} + Md^2 \)
If an object's moment of inertia about its center of mass is known, it can be found about another axis at distance \( d \).

\( L = I \omega \)
Angular momentum is the rotational equivalent of linear momentum.

\( I_1 \omega_1 = I_2 \omega_2 \)
Angular momentum remains constant if no external torque acts on the system.

Planets move in elliptical orbits with the Sun at one focus.
\( r = \frac{a(1 - e^2)}{1 + e \cos \theta} \)

A line from the Sun to a planet sweeps out equal areas in equal times.
\( \frac{dA}{dt} = \frac{1}{2} r^2 \omega = \text{constant} \)

The square of a planet's orbital period is proportional to the cube of its semi-major axis.
\( T^2 \propto a^3 \) or \( T^2 = \frac{4 \pi^2 a^3}{G M} \)

\( F = G \frac{m_1 m_2}{r^2} \)
The force of attraction between two masses is proportional to their product and inversely proportional to the square of the distance.

The velocity required to maintain a stable orbit.
\( v = \sqrt{\frac{GM}{r}} \)

The time taken for one full revolution around a central mass.
\( T = 2\pi \sqrt{\frac{r^3}{GM}} \)

The minimum velocity needed to escape a planet's gravitational field.
\( v_e = \sqrt{\frac{2GM}{r}} \)

\( U = -G \frac{m_1 m_2}{r} \)
The potential energy of a mass in a gravitational field.

The sum of kinetic and potential energy in an orbit.
\( E = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 - G \frac{M m}{r} \)

For a satellite to remain fixed above a point on Earth.
\( T = 24 \text{ hours} \) or \( r = 42,164 \text{ km} \)

The apparent weightlessness in orbit is due to free-fall motion.
\( g' = g - \frac{v^2}{r} \)

The gravitational force per unit mass at a distance from a planet.
\( g = \frac{GM}{r^2} \)

A principle stating that a change in pressure applied to an enclosed fluid is transmitted undiminished throughout the fluid.
\( P_1 = P_2 \) in an incompressible fluid.)

A principle stating that the upward buoyant force exerted on a body submerged in a fluid is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the body.
\( F_b = \rho g V \))

The volume of fluid that passes a given point per unit time.
\( Q = A v \))

A statement of energy conservation for a flowing fluid, stating that the sum of pressure energy, kinetic energy, and potential energy per unit volume remains constant along a streamline.
\( P + \frac{1}{2} \rho v^2 + \rho g h = \text{constant} \))
Thermal physics studies heat, temperature, and energy transfer. It connects macroscopic thermodynamics with microscopic statistical mechanics.

Heat transfer is the process of thermal energy moving due to a temperature difference. The heat required to change temperature is:
\( Q = mc\Delta T \)

Phase changes occur when a substance transitions between solid, liquid, and gas states without changing temperature. The energy required is:
\( Q = mL \) where \( L \) is the latent heat.

Materials expand when heated due to increased molecular motion. The linear expansion formula is:
\( \Delta L = \alpha L_0 \Delta T \)

Heat can be transferred via conduction, convection, and radiation.

Conduction:
\( Q = -k A \frac{dT}{dx} \)

Convection:
\( Q = hA (T_s - T_{\infty}) \)

Radiation:
\( Q = \sigma \epsilon A (T^4 - T_{\infty}^4) \)

Charles' Law: Volume increases with temperature at constant pressure.
\( \frac{V_1}{T_1} = \frac{V_2}{T_2} \)
Boyleâ€™s Law: Pressure and volume are inversely related at constant temperature.
\( P_1 V_1 = P_2 V_2 \)

Describes the state of an ideal gas:
\( PV = nRT \), where \( R = 8.314 \) J/(molÂ·K). It relates pressure, volume, and temperature.

De kinetische gastheorie beschrijft gassen als een verzameling van deeltjes die willekeurig bewegen. De gemiddelde kinetische energie van een gasdeeltje wordt gegeven door:
\( KE_{\text{gem}} = \frac{3}{2} k_B T \)
De gemiddelde snelheid van gasmoleculen wordt berekend met:
\( v_{\text{rms}} = \sqrt{\frac{3 k_B T}{m}} \).
